author: Agence France Presse
title: More than 100 arrested at US university pro-Palestinian protests | The Citizen
text:
More than 100 arrested at US university pro-Palestinian protests More than 100 people were arrested at two universities in California and Texas, officials said, after pro-Palestinian protests erupted across US campuses this week. Pro-Palestine demonstrators argue with USC public safety officers after officers attempted to take down an encampment in support of Gaza at the University of Southern California on April 24, 2024 in Los Angeles, California. Pro-Palestinian encampments have sprung up at college campuses around the country recently. Mario Tama/Getty Images/AFP (Photo by MARIO TAMA / GETTY IMAGES NORTH AMERICA / Getty Images via AFP)
More than 100 people were arrested Wednesday at two universities in California and Texas, officials said, after pro-Palestinian protests erupted across US campuses this week.
Demonstrations flared at the University of Southern California’s (USC) Los Angeles campus, where 93 people were arrested for trespassing, and at the University of Texas (UT) in Austin, where 34 were arrested, according to authorities.
The tense standoffs were among the latest on-campus confrontations between law enforcement, including police in riot gear, and banner-wielding students outraged at the mounting death toll in Israel’s war against Palestinian militant group Hamas.
USC said on social media site X at around midnight that the protest had ended and the campus would remain “closed until further notice.”
“Students, faculty, staff, and people with business on campus may enter with proper identification,” the university said.
Read more ANC can rise again, says Dali Tambo ALSO READ: In bad taste: Biden hints his ‘Uncle Bosie’ was eaten by PNG cannibals
Los Angeles police officers went to the campus on Wednesday afternoon and “assisted the university in effecting trespass arrests” when protesters refused to leave, Captain Kelly Muniz told reporters.
The LAPD said there were no reports of injuries and patrols would remain in the area on Thursday.
Free speech The spreading pro-Palestinian protests began at Columbia University in New York, where dozens of arrests were made last week after university authorities called in police to quell a protest encampment that some Jewish students said was threatening and anti-Semitic.
Demonstrators, including a number of Jewish students, have disavowed instances of anti-Semitism and criticized officials equating it with opposition to Israel.
As students and other demonstrators have camped out on school quads, occupied university buildings and disrupted campus activities, universities this week have affirmed their rights to free speech and peaceful protest.
ALSO READ: More than 50 000 displaced by clashes in northern Ethiopia: UN
But pro-Israel supporters and others worried about campus safety have also pointed to anti-Semitic incidents and allege that campuses are encouraging intimidation and hate speech.
House Speaker Mike Johnson told reporters at Columbia on Wednesday that the demonstrations “place a target on the backs of Jewish students in the United States,” adding that the National Guard could be brought in if the protests were not contained soon.
On Sunday, US President Joe Biden denounced “blatant anti-Semitism” that has “no place on college campuses.”
But the White House has also said that the president supports freedom of expression on US campuses.
Student protesters say they are expressing solidarity with Palestinians in Gaza, where the death toll has topped 34,305, according to the Hamas-run health ministry, and are calling on universities to divest from companies with ties to Israel.
ALSO READ: Tensions flare at US universities over Gaza protests
US ally Israel launched its war in Gaza after the Hamas attack on October 7 that left around 1,170 people dead, according to an AFP tally of Israeli official figures.
– By: © Agence France-Presse

author: Admin
title: Linkenmeyer wins Queen Crown at the MHCF
text:
Linkenmeyer wins Queen Crown at the MHCF
Tue, 07/01/2025 - 4:55pm
admin
By:
Sara York TPD News Editor
CRESCO - Excitement is in the air as the Mighty Howard County Fair celebrates one of the greatest achievements for a young lady in the fair community: becoming Fair Queen! This year, that prestigious title is awarded to the incredible Kennedy Linkenmeyer!
Growing up, surrounded by her family's beef cattle and pigs, Kennedy has poured her heart and soul into caring for her animals. Living with type one diabetes has only fueled her unstoppable spirit. As Kennedy beautifully puts it, "It is not an easy thing to live with, but it has shaped who I am and inspired me to help others while dreaming of one day having a farm with pigs and cattle."
She is a true inspiration, with her sights set on becoming an occupational therapist to make a positive impact on the lives of others.
When she was crowned Queen, Kennedy was completely overjoyed, saying, "I am competing against some great and hardworking women!"
All that hard work truly paid off, and she proudly claimed the title of the 2025 Mighty Howard County Fair Queen! With a fierce passion for representing Howard County, Kennedy is excited to educate children about farms and agriculture and is determined to make remarkable contributions to community improvements. She aims to be a Fair Queen whom everyone can admire and cherish.
As she prepares for an exhilarating week at the upcoming Iowa State Fair, Kennedy can not wait for future Friendship, Learning, Competition, and the vibrant festivities of that special Queen's Week! She dreams of one day becoming the Iowa State Fair Queen!
Kennedy is also grateful to have Kenzie Moellers by her side, who has taken on the role of MHCF Princess. The bond between them is set to grow as they attend various events together.
Kenzie enthusiastically pledged her support, stating, "I will help Kennedy with anything she needs. I will support and be by her side no matter what!"
Together, the Queen and Princess will take on numerous responsibilities, from handing out ribbons to participating in countless events throughout the fair. They are bursting with excitement for the busy year ahead and can't wait to represent Howard County with immense pride.

Un tweet calquiera, que es erroneo por mezclar churras con merina.
Harkon, su clon Delay y el resto del rebaño de meneame a las órdenes de la Chepa Suprema ilustra claramente la situación actual de la estúpida izquierda española, que se encuentra hundida en su propio pozo de mierda, cada día más cerca de la irrelevancia. Todo el día echándose mierda unos a otros encima de sus cabezas tiene las consecuencias que todos sabemos y hemos visto en las últimas 2 elecciones.
Por mi podéis seguir así hasta el infinito. Más votos sacará Alvise, más votos sacará la extrema derecha y más gobiernos formará el PP. Sois unos cracks

author: Chris Walker
title: More Than Half of Americans Don’t Have Enough Savings to Cover $1,000 Expense | Truthout
text:
Israel Doctors Without Borders Slams US for Ceasefire Veto in Devastating UN Address Wisconsin WI Gov Calls On State Supreme Court to Order Changes to Congressional Districts Israel “Gaza Has Become a Death Zone,” World Health Organization Director Warns LGBTQ Rights House Republicans Threaten Government Shutdown in Push for Anti-Trans Policies More About Donate Manage Your Donation More Ways to Give Subscribe Submission Guidelines Financial Information Privacy Policy Memorial Essay Prize Truthout Center for Grassroots Journalism Job Openings Contact Us © 2024 Truthout News | Economy & Labor More Than Half of Americans Don’t Have Enough Savings to Cover $1,000 Expense More than one in five Americans have no emergency savings fund set up at all.
By Chris Walker , T ruthout Published January 25, 2024 Jake Allen via Unsplash A new survey highlights how most Americans would be unable to use their savings in order to pay for an unexpected expense.
While the poll from Bankrate acknowledged the country’s falling inflation numbers and strong employment trends, it added that “many Americans still don’t have enough savings for a rainy day.”
The annual survey, which Bankrate has conducted for the past 13 years, notes that only 44 percent of Americans could pay for a $1,000 emergency through a savings fund they are currently maintaining. The remaining 56 percent of Americans would have to take other actions, with more than a third saying they would be forced to go deeper into debt.
Sixteen percent of Americans would reduce their spending habits elsewhere in order to cover the cost of an emergency, the survey found, while 35 percent would have to borrow money to pay for it, either through taking out a personal loan, paying through credit cards or asking family members or friends for aid. Five percent said they’d “do something else,” an answer which Bankrate didn’t delve into.
The survey also found that 57 percent of Americans are uncomfortable with the amount of savings they have for emergencies. Twenty-two percent of Americans have no emergency fund set up at all — the second lowest rate in Bankrate’s history of polling on the question.
Related Story News | Economy & Labor Greedflation Accounts for 53 Cents of Every Dollar of Inflation in Past 6 Months With the 2024 presidential election looming, 96 percent of Americans say inflation is an important issue to them. By Chris Walker , T ruthout January 22, 2024 Truthout The U.S. has been experiencing numerous positive economic indicators as of late , including low unemployment, a reduction in inflation and continued economic growth over the past year. On Thursday, the Commerce Department announced that the gross domestic product grew by 3.3 percent in the past year .
However, those economic gains aren’t being felt in households across the country, as inflation has raised the costs of goods to the point where most Americans say they are living paycheck-to-paycheck .
The issue is likely to play a major role in the 2024 presidential election. Typically, incumbent presidents are viewed as more vulnerable when the economy isn’t doing well . The fact that most Americans aren’t experiencing the effects of positive economic indicators firsthand could be problematic for President Joe Biden, who is seeking reelection in the fall.
Polling data on the question is indeed alarming for Biden. According to an Economist /YouGov poll published this week , 19 out of 20 registered voters (95 percent) view inflation and rising prices as an important issue. Those voters also gave Biden failing marks on the matter — just 37 percent of registered voters approve of Biden when it comes to inflation and prices, while 58 percent disapprove.
